title:
Positive Dehn Twist Expressions for Some Elements of Finite Order in the
  Mapping Class Group

title_detail.value:
Positive Dehn Twist Expressions for Some Elements of Finite Order in the
  Mapping Class Group

summary:
Positive Dehn twist products for some elements of finite order in the mapping
class group of a 2-dimensional closed, compact, oriented surface $\Sigma_g$,
which are rotations of $\Sigma_g$ through $2\pi /p$, are presented. The
homeomorphism invariants of the resulting simply connected symplectic 4-
manifolds are computed.

summary_detail.value:
Positive Dehn twist products for some elements of finite order in the mapping
class group of a 2-dimensional closed, compact, oriented surface $\Sigma_g$,
which are rotations of $\Sigma_g$ through $2\pi /p$, are presented. The
homeomorphism invariants of the resulting simply connected symplectic 4-
manifolds are computed.

author: Yusuf Z. Gurtas
fulltext:
arXiv:math/0501385v1 [math.GT] 22 Jan 2005

POSITIVE DEHN TWIST EXPRESSIONS FOR SOME
ELEMENTS OF FINITE ORDER IN THE MAPPING CLASS
GROUP
YUSUF Z. GURTAS
Abstract. Positive Dehn twist products for some elements of finite order in
the mapping class group of a 2-dimensional closed, compact, oriented surface
Σg , which are rotations of Σg through 2π/p, are presented. The homeomorphism invariants of the resulting simply connected symplectic 4- manifolds are
computed.

Introduction
Positive Dehn twist expressions for a new set of involutions in the mapping class
group of 2-dimensional closed, compact, oriented surfaces were presented in [1].
In a later article the idea was extended to bounded surfaces and from that, the
positive Dehn twist expressions for involutions on closed surfaces that are obtained
by joining several copies of bounded surfaces together were also obtained, [2]. It
is the purpose of this article to present positive Dehn twist expressions for some
elements of finite order in Mg , which are rotations through 2π/p on the surface Σg .
This is shown in section 2 using the expressions for the involutions described in
[1] . In section 3 the homeomorphism invariants of the resulting simply connected
symplectic 4- manifolds that are realized as Lefschetz fibrations are computed.
1. Review
Let i represent the hyperelliptic (horizontal) involution and s represent the vertical involution as shown in Figure 1.

Figure 1. The vertical and horizontal involutions
1991 Mathematics Subject Classification. Primary 57M07; Secondary 57R17, 20F38.
Key words and phrases. low dimensional topology, symplectic topology, mapping class group,
Lefschetz fibration .
1

 2

YUSUF Z. GURTAS

If i is the horizontal involution on a surface Σh and s is the vertical involution
on a surface Σk , k−even, then let θ be the horizontal involution on the surface Σg ,
where g = h + k, obtained as in Figure 2.

Figure 2. The involution θ on the surface Σh+k
Figure 3 shows the cycles that are used in expressing θ as a product of positive
Dehn twists which is stated in the next theorem.

Figure 3. The cycles used in the expression of θ
Theorem 1.0.1. The positive Dehn twist expression for the involution θ on the
surface Σh+k shown in Figure 3 is given by
θ = c2i+2 * * * c2h c2h+1 c2i * * * c2 c1 b0 c2h+1 c2h * * * c2i+2 c1 c2 * * * c2i b1 b2 * * * bk−1 bk c2i+1 .

 POSITIVE DEHN TWIST EXPRESSIONS FOR SOME ELEMENTS OF FINITE ORDER

3

See [1] for the proof.
The order of the twists is from right to left, i.e., c2i+1 is applied first.
2. Main Results
It is very easy to define many of the elements of finite order in the mapping class
group qualitatively using geometry. In this section we will consider those which are
realized as rotations on the surface Σ1+p through an angle of 2π/p, Figure 4.

Figure 4. 2π/p rotation φp on Σ1+p
It is a very difficult task in general, however, to find a positive Dehn twist
expression for a given finite order element in the mapping class group. In this
section we will find explicit positive Dehn twist expressions for rotations of the
kind described above. To achieve that, we will make use of the expression for the
involution θ that is given in Theorem 1.0.1. p represents a positive odd integer
throughout this section.

Figure 5. Definition of the involutions θ13 and θ23 on Σ1+3
Let φp denote the 2π/p rotation on the surface Σ1+p as shown in Figure 4.
Let θ1p be the involution defined as 180◦ rotation about the axis through the
center of the surface Σ1+p and the hole number (p + 1)/2, Figure 5 (a). Let θ2p

 4

YUSUF Z. GURTAS

be the involution defined as 180◦ rotation about the axis through the center of the
surface Σ1+p and the hole number 1, Figure 5 (b).
It's not difficult to see that application of θ1p followed by θ2p results in 2π/p
rotation about the center of the surface. Application of θ1p on the surface gives the
result shown in Figure 7 (b), and θ2p takes this figure to the result shown in Figure
8 (b).
Note that Figure 8 (b) and Figure 6 (b) are the same, namely the result of
successive applications of the involutions θ1p and θ2p is the same as the action of φp
on the surface Σ1+p . From this we conclude that
φp = θ2p θ1p
on the surface Σ1+p .

Figure 6. 2π/3 rotation φ3 on Σ1+3

Now the question is how to find a positive Dehn twist product for φp . The
answer is simply juxtaposing the positive Dehn twist expressions for θ1p and θ2p .
Therefore, we first need to get those expressions for θ1p and θ2p using Theorem 1.0.1.
Figure 9 shows the cycles that realize θ13 on the surface Σ1+3 using Theorem
1.0.1. Similarly, Figure 10 shows the cycles that realize θ23 on the surface Σ1+3
using the same theorem.
According to Theorem 1.0.1 we have
θ13 = c14 c13 c12 c11 b10 c11 c12 c13 c14 b11 b12 c15
and
θ23 = c24 c23 c22 c21 b20 c21 c22 c23 c24 b21 b22 c25 .
Therefore
φ3 = θ23 θ13 = c24 c23 c22 c21 b20 c21 c22 c23 c24 b21 b22 c25 c14 c13 c12 c11 b10 c11 c12 c13 c14 b11 b12 c15 .

 POSITIVE DEHN TWIST EXPRESSIONS FOR SOME ELEMENTS OF FINITE ORDER

5

Figure 8. Involution θ23 applied to the result from Figure 7
Since φ33 = 1, we have

in M4 , the mapping class group of the surface Σ4 .
Next, we will demonstrate the cycles used in the expression for φ3 on a regular
genus 4 surface Σ4 and generalize it. For this, we need an identification between
the two surfaces Σ4 and Σ1+3 . Figure 11 shows that identification.
Figure 12 shows the same identification for general case. The hole with no
number on the right is the hole in the center on the left.

YUSUF Z. GURTAS

Figure 10. Involution θ23 on Σ1+3 and the cycles that realize it

Figure 13 shows the cycles in Figure 9 (b) via the identification established in
Figure 11. Similarly, Figure 14 shows the cycles in Figure 10 (b) via the identification established in Figure 11.

Figure 13. The cycles realizing θ13 on Σ4

 8

YUSUF Z. GURTAS

Figure 14. The cycles realizing θ23 on Σ4
In general, the cycles realizing φp on the round surface Σ1+p are carried onto the
regular surface Σp+1 using the identification in Figure 12.

3. Applications
Let Σg be the 2-dimensional, closed, compact, oriented surface of genus g > 0
and Mg be its mapping class group, the group of isotopy classes of all orientationpreserving diffeomorphisms Σg → Σg . It is a well-known fact that any word in the
mapping class group Mg that contains positive exponents only and is equal to the
identity element defines a symplectic Lefschetz fibration X 4 → S 2 . In this section
we compute the homeomorphism invariants of the symplectic Lefschetz fibrations
that are defined by the words φpp = 1, p− odd, in Mp+1 .

Figure 15. Standard generators of π1 (Σp+1 )
First, we will show that the 4− manifold X carrying the symplectic Lefschetz
fibration structure X 4 → S 2 is simply connected. A well known fact in theory of
Lefschetz fibrations states that π1 (X) is isomorphic to the quotient of π1 (Σp+1 )

 POSITIVE DEHN TWIST EXPRESSIONS FOR SOME ELEMENTS OF FINITE ORDER

9

by the normal subgroup generated by the vanishing cycles, the cycles about which
positive Dehn twists in the expression φpp = 1 are performed. The vanishing cycles
are seen as elements of π1 (Σp+1 ) in this section, not as elements of Mg+1 .
Let {α1 , β1 , * * * , βp+1 , αp+1 } be the set of standard 2p+2 generators of π1 (Σp+1 )
as shown in Figure 15. We will show that the subgroup of π1 (Σp+1 ) generated by
the vanishing cycles includes all the generators of π1 (Σp+1 ) by showing that each
generator is equal to 1 in the quotient group. We will use the elements in π1 (Σp+1 )
that are shown in Figure 16 along with the standard generators to express the
vanishing cycles as elements of π1 (Σp+1 ). The expressions should be read from
right to left.

 POSITIVE DEHN TWIST EXPRESSIONS FOR SOME ELEMENTS OF FINITE ORDER

respectively. Using c21 = αq+1 = 1 we see that αq+2 = 1. If αq+2 = 1, then
αq = 1 and if αq = 1, then αq+3 = 1, etc. Continuing this was we can conclude
that α3 = α4 = * * * = αp+1 = 1 in the quotient π1 (Σp+1 ) /N, which is isomorphic
to π1 (X), and this concludes the proof.
We do not know a topological argument to determine what those simply connected symplectic 4− manifolds are but we can compute their homeomorphism invariants using the symplectic Lefschetz fibration structure that they support. This
will be accomplished by computing the Euler characteristics and the signatures of
those Lefschetz fibrations .
Another fact that we will borrow from the theory of Lefschetz fibrations is the
fact that the Euler characteristic of such a fibration X 4 → S 2 is given by the
formula
χ(X) = 4 − 4g + s,
where s is the number of singular fibers, i.e., the number of vanishing cycles.

φpp

From 3.0.1 we see that each of θ1p and θ2p consists of p + 9 cycles. Therefore
p
= (θ2p θ1p ) consists of
2p (p + 9)

cycles and the Euler characteristic is found to be
χ(X) = 4 − 4(p + 1) + 2p (p + 9)
= 2p2 + 14p
= 2p (p + 7) .
In order to compute the signature σ(X) we wrote a Matlab program using the
algorithm described in [3]. The computations that we have done using this program
point to the closed formula
σ(X) = −12p
for the signature. Taking this formula for granted we can conclude that
c21 (X) = 3σ (X) + 2χ (X)
= 3 (−12p) + 2 * 2p (p + 7)
= 4p (p − 2)
and

σ (X) + χ (X)
4
−12p + 2p (p + 7)
=
4
1
= p (p + 1) .

χh (X) =

YUSUF Z. GURTAS

χh (X) in the above computation makes sense because X has almost complex
structure.

of p.
